page.title: 20Local history,Swainby&Potto
page.content: {Trenholme,}meaning "marshy land of the cranes", was drained in mediaeval times by a deep stell which has needed regular maintenance through the centuries. It also serves as a parish boundary. West Lees, the{oldest farm-} {house site,}dates from the 13th C or earlier, being the Demesne farm of the Lords Meynill of Whorlton Castle. {Oxhill}dates from the 16th C. Two deerparks, now farmland, lie south and east of Swainby. In the 18th C{Potto} was a linen weaving and bleaching centre; a tilery provided drain and pantiles. A mineral branch line from Potto Station to Swainby, opened in 1857 for the removal of ironstone, was dismantled c.1905. The{drove road}from Yarm to York lies just west of Swainby. A{pinfold,}now converted to a public garden, remains in Swainby. SWAINBY & POTTO WOMEN'S INSTITUTE
